did.abstract: Collection consist primarily of Shaffer's Newsweek files (telexes, carbons, xeroxes of what he filed during his tenure with that news magazine) and typescripts of his book "On and Off the Floor." Both the files and the book typescripts are heavily annotated by Shaffer.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Samuel Shaffer papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Samuel Shaffer (1910-1995) received his bachelor of arts degree in 1931 from The George Washington University, graduating cum laude. He pursued graduate study at the University of Michigan (1931) and at the University of Chicago (1932-1933). He began his journalist career as a reporter From 1936-42, for the "Washington Herald," later the "Washington Times Herald." From 1942-45, he served as a combat correspondent in the U.S. Marines Corps. For his military service in, World War II, Shaffer received the Purple Heart, two battle stars, and the Presidential Unit Citation. After his military service, Shaffer was employed by "Newsweek" magazine as a reporter in New York city (1945-46) and in 1947 was promoted to Chief Congressional Correspondent, a position which he held until 1975.

In 1945 Shaffer's first book, "Betio Beachhead: U.S. Marines' Own Story of the Battle for Tarawa," co-authored with Earl J. Wilson, Jim G. Lucas and C. Peter Zurlinden, was published by G.P. Putnam's Sons. His second book, "On and Off the Floor: Thirty Years as a Correspondent on Capitol Hill," was published by "Newsweek" in 1980. Shaffer is a member of the National Press Club, the White House Correspondents Association, the Periodical Galleries Association, of which he was president (1975-76), and The George Washington University Faculty and Alumni Club.

Samuel Shaffer was born in Washington, D.C. on July 10, 1910 to Morris and Fannie (Siegel) Shaffer. On July 9, 1933 he married a fellow-journalist, Helen Buchalter. They had three children. Helen died on July 18, 1978. Mr. Shaffer died in 1995.
[This exerpt is from Locher, Frances C. Contem orar Authors Volume 104 (Michigan: Gale Research Company, 1982), 424.]

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consist primarily of Shaffer's Newsweek files (telexes, carbons, xeroxes of what he filed during his tenure with that news magazine) and typescripts of his book "On and Off the Floor." Both the files and the book typescripts are often annotated by Shaffer.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: Chronological files, Correspondence, and Book typescript.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: series contains Shaffer's copy filed for various sections of "Newsweek" (Nation, Washington Trends, Foreign, Periscope, "Biz", etc.) from 1948-75, final stories on the 1976 presidential campaign, revisions of the stories (addenda/corrections), interviews, and correspondence with his New York editors. Shaffer's submissions are most numerous on Congressional activities, other stories deal with specific pieces of legislation, such as Taft-Hartley, labor, farm, school, trade, and crime bills, government agencies and commissions (CIA, Voice of America, Supreme Court, FBI, SEC, and USIA), military issues; and espionage/un-American activities. Other submissions focus on economic issues, social concerns such as civil rights, welfare, poverty and housing. There are a also a number of files covering disarmament, the U-2 incident, the Cuban crisis, the Nuclear Proliferation and Test Ban treaties, as well as U.S. involvement in the Middle East and Indochina (Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam). Much of the material in this series has never appeared in print.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence. The letters date from 1979-82. These letters are business and congratulatory correspondence pertaining to Shaffer's book, "On and Off the Floor." There are letters from Shaffer and letters to Shaffer. The letters written by Shaffer between June 1979 and January 1982 concerning publication and, promotion of "On and Off the Floor." Shaffer in some instances, identifies the recipient of a specific letter by means of hand-written notation at the top of that particular letter. Among the several recipients identified in this manner are: Herbert Gordon (editor of Shaffer's book), former President Gerald Ford, and Peter Derow (Chairman and President of Newsweek in February 1981). Other letters are original or photocopied business and congratulatory letters received by either Shaffer or the staff at Newsweek Books between February 1979 and October 1982 regarding "On and Off the Floor." The subject matter of these is either promotional comments for the book, expressions of gratitude for the receipt of a copy of the book, or messages of congratulations on the publication of the book. A few of the letters deal with royalties for the book. Many of the correspondents of these letters are well-known; others are associated with Newsweek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains two early typescripts of "On and Off the Floor" (the second one has heavy manuscript annotations), inserts and revisions, a retyped typescript of the book, and the author's galleys of the book. "On and Off the Floor" is based on Shaffer's Newsweek submissions. The book, dedicated to the memory of his wife, is Shaffer's reminiscences of political personalities and events from McCartyism to Richard Nixon's abdication of the presidency.
